captions.text: (applause)

Mr. Jones:
When I found out that I had a chance to come to the White
House to deliver two or three minutes in the realm of poetry,

I immediately thought
of Dr. Seuss --
(laughter)

-- or William Shakespeare
and then I remembered that --

how Jesse Jackson had so
well acquitted himself with
Dr. Seuss' Green Eggs and Ham.
(laughter)
You remember that; thank you.

So I decided that best
I stick with Shakespeare.
And I'm going to read General Othello's testimony before the
Senate of Venice to defend himself against the charge of

witchcraft -- in particular,
of bewitching Desdemona,

the daughter of
Senator Brabantio.

Most potent, grave,
and reverend signiors,

My very noble and
approved good masters,

That I have taken away
this good man's daughter,

It is most true; true,
I've married her.

The very head and
front of my offending

Hath this extent, no more.
Rude am I in my speech,

And little bless'd with
the soft phrase of peace:

For since these arms of
mine had seven years' pith,

Til now some nine moons
wasted, they have used

Their dearest action
in the tented field,

And little of this
great world can I speak,

More than pertains to
feats of broil and battle,

And therefore little
shall I grace my cause

In speaking for myself. Yet,
by your gracious patience,

I will a round
unvarnish'd tale deliver

Of my whole course of love;
what drugs, what charms,

What conjuration and
what mighty magic,

For such proceeding
I am charged withal,

Her father loved
me; oft invited me;

Still question'd me
the story of my life,

From year to year, the
battles, sieges, fortunes,
I have passed.

I ran it through, even
from my boyish days,

To the very moment
he bade me tell it;

Wherein I spoke of most
disastrous chances,

Of moving accidents
by flood and field

Of hair-breadth scapes in
the imminent deadly breach,

Of being taken by
the insolent foe

And sold to slavery,
of my redemption thence

And portance in my
travels' history:

Wherein of antres
vast and deserts idle,

Rough quarries, rocks and
hills whose heads touch heaven

It was my hint to
speak,--such was the process;

And of the Cannibals
that each other eat,

The Anthropophagi
and men whose heads
Do grow beneath their shoulders -- ha ha ha ha -- This to hear

Would Desdemona
seriously incline:

But still the house-affairs
would draw her thence:

Which ever as she could
with haste dispatch,

She'd come again,
and with a greedy ear

Devour up my discourse:
which I observing,

Took once a pliant hour,
and found good means

To draw from her a
prayer of earnest heart

That I would all my
pilgrimage dilate,

Whereof by parcels she
had something heard,

But not intentively:
I did consent,

And often did beguile
her of her tears,

When I did speak of
some distressful stroke

my youth suffer'd.
My story being done,

She gave me for my
pains a world of tears:

She swore, in faith, twas
strange, 'twas passing strange,

'Twas pitiful, 'twas
wondrous pitiful:

She wish'd she had not
heard it, and yet she wish'd

That heaven had made for her
such a man: she thank'd me,

And bade me, if I had a
friend that loved her,

I should but teach him
how to tell my story.

And that would woo her.
Upon this hint I spoke:

She loved me for the
dangers I have pass'd,

And I loved her that
she did pity them.

This only is the
witchcraft I have used:
(applause and cheering)

title: James Earl Jones Performs Shakespeare at the White House Poetry Jam: (3 of 8)

comments.text:
I am watching this and many others for inspiration on the role on Othello. 
None yet have I seen that have impacted upon me as this one has.﻿
comments.author: Daniel Wilde

comments.text:
In the early 80s I saw Jones as Othello on Broadway. Christopher Plummer 
was Iago. Jones was magnificent with that thunderous voice, and Plummer was 
a revelation with the charm of a cobra. Both actors should do Lear, and 
Jones is ripe for Falstaff.﻿
comments.author: itgetseasierlessitry

comments.text: James Earl Jones starwar
comments.author: sergio bregante

comments.text:
Hey There! Thanks a lot for this useful video. By the way, I hear many 
people keep on talking about Stutterolax Secrets (do a google search), but 
I'm not sure if it's good. Have you thought about system called Stutterolax 
Secrets? I've heard some incredible things about it and my buddy completely 
stop his stuttering naturally with this system.
comments.author: jacque r.marshal

comments.text:
Also saw him on opening night at the Arena Theatre in DC, in the starring 
role of boxer Jack Johnson in "The Great White Hope".
comments.author: Lea Adams

comments.text:
I saw him play Macbeth and Macduff on consecutive nights in Joe Papp's 
Shakespeare in the Park performances (circa 1965). It was one of the first 
"non-traditional" productions using Black and white actors in roles 
formerly played only by whites.
comments.author: Lea Adams

comments.text: MUFASA!!!
comments.author: Lincoln Campbell

comments.text:
His delivery is kind of fruity for someone who's supposed to be a war

comments.author: Keelan Watlington

comments.text:
The whole purpose of this soliloquy is to get Othello off the hook. As in 
all of Willie's plays, words are the great movers. Ironically, it's Iago's 
masterful use of words which seal Othello's fate.
comments.author: fgonzalez43

comments.text: This vessel of talent.... just becomes and is.....
comments.author: Akke Draijer-de Jong

comments.text:
A love grounded on pity in a relationship will not last because neither are 
on equal footing. Same as the caregiver/patient Florence Nightingale 
effect, the Stockholm Syndrome, the teacher/student, etc. Real love is 
between equals in equal roles. Sorry, it won't work in any other way.
comments.author: thedesignhighschool

comments.text:
NO, it's the voice of GOD that shook those people. And I wish they'd bring 
back Tex Murphy so gamers can go back to church again! When you did 
something truly stoopid, Tex would get chewed out by God...and sent back to 
save the world *snortle* But seriously, if you get the chance to see him 
live....RUN for it, because if you think this sounds good...try it in a 
room like THAT!
comments.author: ThyGeekGoddess Muze

comments.text:
Funny. But it's a Shakespearean who voiced Mufasa and Darth Vader, 
God...and the list is long and distinguished. This means a lot to me. When 
we went to see him at Ford's, (I think), I was so excited, we were on Rt 50 
before I realized, I'd left my glasses and Dad wouldn't turn back. The 
other senses took over. Dad was right. JEJ's a powerful spirit the 
acoustics were fantabulous, but I always wanted to SEE him do it. Just as 
well, he would have jump-started puberty back then. '78 or so.
comments.author: ThyGeekGoddess Muze

comments.text:
I'll have to say Othello used the word 'pity' for those he addressed. 
Knowing the deep ca-ca he'd be in, had he not taken the humble road, he 
said, "pity". They had his life in their hands. What was he going to say, 
"She'd never met a real man, before?" She asked him to teach a suitor how 
to tell a story? Yah, right. As if anyone but he, who lived through it 
could tell THAT story, or any other of HIS experiences. A really good 
writer/storyteller can empathize with the hero.
comments.author: ThyGeekGoddess Muze

comments.text: Too bad women aren't usually attracted to men they pity.

Jones. Bravo
